cs.IT, cs.ITP, cs.CR, cs.DS, cs.SI. 

The paper deals with information theory and its application to polarization, which suggests that it is likely to belong to the cs.IT (Information Theory) sub-category. Additionally, the paper may also fall under cs.ITP (Information Theory and Probability), as it deals with probability pairs. The paper also mentions the Bhattacharyya parameter, which is commonly used in cryptography and security, indicating that it may belong to the cs.CR (Cryptography and Security) sub-category. The study of polarization may also involve graph theory, which falls under the cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms) sub-category. Finally, the paper discusses the micro scale of polarization, which may involve machine learning and pattern recognition, suggesting that it may also belong to the cs.SI (Social and Information Networks) sub-category.
